instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan High
threads.message:
Liquid on a few spots. J4800, <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, some around SMC as well. Replaced J4800, touched up SMC area as well as reflow and touched up 55110 area. Replaced I/O Board and cable, as well as TP cable. Fans still high. Ran Apple Diags and Im getting SMC error and Camera error. Fans high with or without camera connected. Any direction will be appreciated. 

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan High
threads.message: Does anyone know where I can start with this one? Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan High
threads.message: Run HWmonitor and see if any of the sensors really high

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan High
threads.message:
Ambient Light Sensor uses same camera connector.
And ALS is connected in the same bus with various temp sensors...
Try a complete LCD assembly, to discard ALS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan High
threads.message: Thanks for the info. Will check and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan High
threads.message:
Hi!
Sorry for the delayed response, I got sidetracked and just got back to this one. 
I tried the full display assembly with the same result. HWMonitor showed that the issue was with CPU Sensor. SMBUS _SMC_SDA was fluctuating. Followed that line to <CHIP>U5620</CHIP>, where there was a tiny bit of corrosion that I missed. Replaced <CHIP>U5620</CHIP> and all is good. 
Thanks alot guys for your help!
